displayed_text: Patient: For the nerves. Doctor: Napercin is a – for – like Ibuprofen uh like you had something for your bathroom Patient: That - That was a long time ago. Patient: Yes. Yep. Doctor: And atorvastatin forty milligrams times a day? Patient: Yep. Doctor: A pro-antibiotic once a day? Patient: Yep. Doctor: Calcium or Vitamin B once a day? Patient: Yep. Doctor: Cranberry extract once a day? Patient: Yep.

Patient: No. Doctor: What do I have to get together again? What? Hey, you guys are wearing the same shirt. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: Is that on purpose for filming? Family Member: No. Oh, I don’t know. (Laughter) Doctor: Okay. I was just checking. My other couple also dressed up but she was in blue and he was in pink. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: It looked like they should be in a catalog. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So, I wasn’t sure if it was like Tigers day or. Family Member: I know. Yes. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Just working zone. (Laughter)

Healthcare Professional: This is the one you take in the morning and at night. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So - that’s why I said if I give you the Percocet it’s going to lower your dose of OxyContin. Patient: Okay, okay. Doctor: But if that works for you I’m good with that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If it doesn’t work we’ll have to go back to the other OxyContin. Patient: Original. Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because that’s what you asked for. Patient: Right.

Family Member: Mm Hmm. Doctor: So we did tissue testing because one of the ways of resistance is if they had that P10 loss which your tissue did. And that’s why we put you on this uh medication that at least you’ve tolerated amazingly well. I mean you really haven’t had any side effects, haven’t felt any different, managed to keep up with everything you want to do. So that’s been remarkable. The PSA last couple of times as we discussed last time has been going up. Okay. One of my concerns is if it keeps going up but the scans don’t change, do we stay the same course? And honestly for how well you’re doing, that’s what I’m tempted to do. Okay. If however your bone scan shows me new areas or things growing then we are going to stop this treatment and go to something else. Patient: I see. Doctor: Now as we sort of discussed a little bit, the something else could either be going back and doing chemotherapy with Dr. K____ okay that’s a potential option. And, or if we want to give it one more try with doing a different kind of hormonal therapy, we have a new hormone therapy agent that we are testing here you know that’s been through multiple people who have had it and there’s been some promising results initially so I think that would be another option. Patient: Mm Hmm. Doctor: But you know so those are probably the potential choices. The third possible choice and that would depend on your CAT scans had some lymph nodes though that were seen so there is a study with a combination of two different therapies. Okay? One is the Xofigo which is a radiation treatment that’s approved. You’ve probably heard of it I know. Family Member: Mm Hmm. Doctor: It’s a treatment that only goes to the bones in prostate cancer and helps kill the cancer in the bones. Most of your disease was in the bones. Okay but you also had lymph nodes in the belly that were related to the prostate cancer. Patient: Oh. Family Member: No I didn’t know that. Okay. Doctor: So at least on the up front CAT scan, not the latest one. Family Member: Oh, oh, oh

Family Member: Because you need the hormone to kill the cancer? Doctor: Yeah. Which is why it’s not going to be like you have hair loss and all that because it’s not a chemo, per se, but it’ll shut it down. Yep. Cool. Okay. All right. Patient: That’s about it. Doctor: Um hum. Keep the phone, not the paperwork. I’ll check my e-mail and see where we are, and if you have to go make some phone calls, C___, you’ll know what to do. Family Member: I need the pharmacy to call me or go harass somebody. Patient: Good luck with that. (Laughs)

Patient: Yes. Doctor: If it was clear cut growth I’m not gonna keep you on something that’s not helping you. Patient: Right. Doctor: You know I would tell you ditch this and just go get some other treatment. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: So for now we gave you the pills for today. Patient: Right. Doctor: So for now you’re okay with keeping on taking it. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay and uh we’ll touch base, we’ll let you know of course what the bone scan shows once I look at it. Okay. Family Member 2: Very good. Doctor: Alright. Patient: What do you think. Yeah, Yepthat’s fine.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. in scheduling your appointment and ask you the possible – he maybe to see this Friday. But I think if he can see you this week, than Patient: Okay. Doctor: a lot of information and try to look over that consent form. Patient: I will. Thank you. Doctor: Alright. I like this plan. Doctor: Nice to see you again. Patient: Good seeing you. Doctor: Alright. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Then please let me know and we will not do this with you, just give you the routine treatment. Okay. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: So, I just wanted to s-stop there at the moment and I want to give you this piece of paper so you can look at it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um and do you have any questions about any of that because I know it can be quite complicated and uh information. Doctor: Exactly. The the good thing about this trial I did not mention, I think I should, um there’s no placebo involved. So there are some studies where they give people um a sugar pill or basically inactive medication. This trial does not involve a placebo. And also in this trial, in both groups, both of you get the Xtandi by itself or the Xtandi plus the new experimental drug active therapy. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: So there there isn’t a but you’re not getting any therapy or you’re getting only a pla-placebo potentially. So, in response to what you just said which is you you wanna get some drug back into your system- Patient: Yup. Doctor: That the clinical trial will give you the option of doing that um potentially with something experimental out and on- Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But not necessarily. Um just a couple of words about the side effects and they’re all listed in this consent form which is fourteen pages long, so it’s quite detailed. But um the main side effects are listed in section four and I will read that with you so you can look at it. We have seen some fatigue with this medication.

Family Member: but sometimes he gets snacks he shouldn’t have. Doctor: Yep. Family Member: But there’s not Metformin so we don’t have anything to combat all these sweets. So we need Doctor: Was he not taking Metformin at all? Family Member: No he’s got – they told him – and they reminded him today because of the alteration in his kidney function, Doctor: Oh okay because of that. Family Member: it would not be a good idea. His doctor took him off. His primary care doctor Doctor: Mm Hmm. Family Member: before all this treatment even started. Doctor: Really? Family Member: She was like… Doctor: Well now that his kidney function is improving, we may be able to restart it if your sugars keep on being high. Okay so next time what I’m gonna suggest is that we get fasting bloodwork

Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: Okay? I think that’s really critical for the first few weeks. Family Member: Okay. Great. Doctor: Slowly both of us will get a good sense of how you’re tolerating this, how things are going, and, obviously, if it’s working, we keep going with it. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: If it’s not helping you, I’m going to stop the treatment. No matter which treatment you’re on. If it’s not working, not helping you, I will tell you that, and I will take you off of the stuff. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: But the good news is there are a number of different treatments. Uh, you know, this one is worth a try, but otherwise there are hormonal pills or other really effective things, too, that we can use outside of the study. Okay? Family Member: So, we don’t have to go through the study? Doctor: So what we’re going to ask is we will make a request, as long as you’re okay with it, to see if the study is accepting new people and if, you know, we’ll send you a case description in. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: As long as but I need your okay for that. Patient: Okay.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.disagree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::disagree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.disagree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::disagree

Which of the following best describe you.Unemployed for 1 year or more: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Unemployed for 1 year or more

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Family Member: Okay. Doctor: That’s why I’m saying that that’s um you know I’ll do that twice just so… Family Member: Okay. Patient: You know I got an appointment with you later in June does that cancel? Doctor: No we’ll cancel that because we don’t need it. Yeah don’t worry about that. (Laughs) Patient: Well I was just wondering. Doctor: Yeah we’ll figure that out. Family Member: Never mind then. Doctor: Depending on the cryo if you decide to go with that and all of that and when Dr. C____ does it, then your next appointments will be changed Patient: Yep. Doctor: according to that. Okay? Patient: Yep. Doctor: Sound like a plan?

Patient: And how soon would that start? Doctor: Uh that would be more—again, based on scans and scheduling. Patient: Okay and then who’s going to order the scans? Doctor: So that’s what I’ve got to talk to Dr. G__ about. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So if you’ve already got the test scans, what’s the plan? Because we need to get pictures to sort of say yes, you’ve progressed. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: I mean I could do that. You know I just want to make sure that if he’s you know ultimately if he’s going to get you chemotherapy and the closer you get to there and that can be given anywhere, Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: you know we might just let that system do it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If that’s where you’ve had them before for comparison sakes, then - Patient: I haven’t had chemo there.

Patient: Yeah. I don’t understand it. Doctor: I think it’s, it’s, well, because the earth’s a circle, globe. (Sound Door opens) Patient: Oh. Oh. Doctor: If you fly straight it’s longer. Patient: Right. Oh. Doctor: Because I don’t quite understand it. Patient: I didn’t know that. Doctor: But, yeah, like when you fly- Patient: I was trying to- Doctor: Like when you fly to Europe, you kind of fly up over, like if you’re going to England, you fly up over Greenland and down. Patient: Yeah. That’s what they did. That’s exactly what they did. Doctor: It’s shorter somehow. Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: You could get regular Taxotere, Taxotere forever if you wanted to. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now your hands and feet won’t let you do it because you might get numb. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Uh, you know, numb hands and feet, but in general the trial allows you to do that and then if you’re not on the vitamin C everybody starts to get the vitamin C. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You kind of pretty much know if you are on the vitamin C though. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because you do get flushing and you know kind of like what you think about high-dose vitamins. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, so I think it’s worth a go at least to think about it.

Patient: Uh, I don’t know, I guess I’d be alright. I’m back walking. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I couldn’t walk then. It got bad. Doctor: Gosh. Patient: I went to the hospital. Doctor: Yeah. Gosh. Could you, uh, uh breathe without oxygen? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Yeah? That was okay? Patient: They put a, they put a little thing in the nose. Doctor: Okay. But I see you don’t need it. So that’s a good sign. Did they give antibiotics while you were there? Patient: Not, not with me. Family Member: Not to take home.
